description: From Middle English lewis, of uncertain origin. Possibly from Old French lous, plural of lou, loup (“the name of a kind of siege engine”, literally “wolf”); or related to clevis.

entries.meaning: A cramp iron inserted into a cavity in order to lift heavy stones; used as a symbol of strength in Freemasonry.
(by extension, figurative) The son of a Freemason, envisaged as assisting his father in heavy work or in old age.
A kind of shears used in cropping woollen cloth.
examples: After the preeming period, the lads are put either to the gig-machines, or to the lewises in the cutting or shearing-room.
